article.headline: Nebraska 71, Arkansas-Pine Bluff 42
article.story: LINCOLN, Neb. (AP) -- After missing the season's first three games, it didn't take long for Nebraska's Marcus Perry to make his presence known against Arkansas-Pine Bluff, with the senior guard hitting two three-pointers in an 11-point flourish that pushed the Cornhuskers to a 71-42 victory Monday. Perry had arthroscopic knee surgery on Nov. 9 and also injured his foot before the season started. He came out on the court Monday ready to play, but a bit unsure of how he would perform. "I was a little worried at first," he said. "I thought I was going to be out of rhythm a little bit. After I knocked the first (3-pointer) down, I knew it was going to be a good night for me." Perry finished with 11 points, hitting four of his nine shots, and pulled down four rebounds. Aleks Maric led the Cornhuskers with 19 points. Perry is going to help Nebraska's offense, coach Doc Sadler said. "He came in for 20 minutes after being out three weeks and he scored 11 points," Sadler said. "More importantly, he hit some threes against their zone." Perry's back-to-back 3-point shots triggered a first-half Husker spurt that put Nebraska firmly in control of the game. Nebraska (4-0) used a stifling defense to shut down Arkansas-Pine Bluff (0-4), holding the Golden Lions to just three of 10 field goals to open the game and forcing 13 turnovers that led to 20 Cornhusker points. Nebraska rang up 11 points in 75 seconds with Perry hitting back to back three-point shots, Ryan Anderson converting a fast-break layup and Charles Richardson nailing a 3-pointer that made the score 19-4 with 11:40 left in the half. The Huskers went up 20, at 26-6, on Maric's free throws with 7:59 remaining in the period. The Golden Lions could not cut the lead below 17 even though Nebraska had two walk-on players on the floor in the final minutes of the half. Arkansas-Pine Bluff's poor shooting continued in the second half. The Golden Lions hit just one of their first 13 shots after halftime, falling behind 61-26 on Maric's free throws with 9:02 left. "Overall, I thought our intensity was pretty good," Sadler said. "We've just got a big week ahead of us." Nebraska hosts North Texas Wednesday before flying to New Jersey to play Rutgers on Saturday. With the win, Sadler becomes the first Nebraska head coach to open his career with four straight victories since Paul Schlisser, who went 6-0 to open the 1919-20 season.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover
